timeline.bodyText: I would expect you'd want to [END functions_ocr_process] here and start it just before accept().
timeline.author: lesv

replies.bodyText: Done.
replies.author: ace-n

timeline.bodyText: This method seems a bit tiny and pointless as a teaching example - it really only has a single significant line.  I wonder if you might want to do this a bit differently?
timeline.author: lesv

replies.bodyText:
I was copying the Node example.
(Though I agree this might be worth refactoring - detectText is a borderline "God method", so maybe we should move the Pub/Sub publishing code to this method instead?)
replies.author: ace-n

replies.bodyText: Let's keep things simple and only ask the user to follow one method.
replies.author: lesv

timeline.bodyText: Why do we do this?
timeline.author: lesv

replies.bodyText: Just because you use a try w/ resources doesn't mean you need to ever catch anything.
replies.author: lesv

replies.bodyText:
The Base BackgroundFunction type in the Functions Framework can only throw subclasses of RuntimeException, which these are not.
(IntelliJ requires the exception to be addressed in a catch block - even if that block merely ignores the error.)
replies.author: ace-n

replies.bodyText:
https://google.github.io/styleguide/javaguide.html#s6.2-caught-exceptions
Also see Effective Java v3 Exceptions

Item 69: Use exceptions only for exceptional conditions
Item 70: Use checked exceptions for recoverable conditions and runtime exceptions for programming errors
Item 71: Avoid unnecessary use of checked exceptions
Item 72: Favor the use of standard exceptions
Item 73: Throw exceptions appropriate to the abstraction
Item 74: Document all exceptions thrown by each method
Item 77: Don’t ignore exceptions
replies.author: lesv

replies.bodyText: What if you just say throws IOException ?
replies.author: lesv

replies.bodyText:
Ah - so (some of) these seem more like "checked" exceptions.
In that case, maybe it would be better to log them and exit the function?
replies.author: ace-n

replies.bodyText:
Spoke with lesv@ about this - initial thoughts are that the best case would be to add a FunctionException (ala  ServerletException) to the Functions framework interface for handling these type of things.  Would you mind opening an issue for this?
A reasonable workaround until that is added is log (with Logger.error) in the meantime.
replies.author: kurtisvg

replies.bodyText: Please log over RuntimeException everywhere.
replies.author: kurtisvg

Added a log statement.
I'm somewhat reluctant to throw an exception here, as this could be caused by bad user input (as opposed to programmer error.)

replies.bodyText: Spoke with Les - we should use getters/setter from outside of the class (like where you linked) but make sure to use the internal reference (like in fromPubSubData).

(This would have to be fixed in the Functions Framework itself. If you'd like, I can file an issue.)

timeline.bodyText: Is there a reason why we are splitting this class into two functions? Seems like it makes it harder to copy/paste
timeline.author: kurtisvg

replies.bodyText:
The existing samples do that. (@lesv had similar feedback)
If you'd like, I can move the Pub/Sub publishing code to functions_ocr_process since detectText is quite long.

replies.bodyText: Done.
replies.author: ace-n

timeline.bodyText: This isn't imported from anywhere? Is it supposed to be com.google.pubsub.v1.PubsubMessage?
timeline.author: kurtisvg

timeline.bodyText: Any reason not to make this a com.google.pubsub.v1.PubsubMessage instead of byte[]?
timeline.author: kurtisvg

replies.bodyText:
There's also a PubSubMessage (capitalized s) POJO here, that's necessary for deserializing incoming Pub/Sub events.
(I tried deserializing into the com.google.pubsub.v1.PubsubMessage type, but the default Gson deserializer couldn't handle it. Longer-term, we should probably write a custom deserializer for this class within the Pub/Sub client library.)
#fyi @chingor13
replies.author: ace-n

timeline.bodyText: Don't need to throw unchecked exceptions
timeline.author: kurtisvg

replies.bodyText: Per your comment below, I moved this into the constructor.
replies.author: ace-n

timeline.bodyText: com.google.pubsub.v1.PubsubMessage looks like it has a getData that returns a String. Can you use that instead of decoding?
timeline.author: kurtisvg

replies.bodyText: See conversation above - it doesn't (yet) work with Cloud Functions' event de-serialization logic.

timeline.bodyText:
Please use java.time for this instead.  You can use something like Instance.now().minus(5, MINUTES)
Additionally, this check doesn't actually verify it worked when run in parallel (as we do with our unit tests).

Replaced this with a UUID'd filename + existence check. 🙂
(The downside is that this also required implementing teardown code.)
